newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila to finish talks with rebels by June.
newsitem.headline: Manila to finish talks with rebels by June.

text.p: Government and communist rebel negotiators may complete their talks on ending a 28-year Marxist insurgency in the Philippines by June, President Fidel Ramos said on Sunday.
Ramos expressed hope in a statement that "the momentum of talks ... would be sustained until a final peace settlement is attained".
Ramos issued the statement after a government panel and the National Democratic Front (NDF) on Saturday ended an eight-day meeting in the Dutch city of Utrecht, which is hosting the negotiations.
Many of the leaders of the NDF, a communist-led umbrella group of 13 leftist organisations, live in exile in the Netherlands.
Ramos said the government panel informed him the talks would resume in March "with the end in view of targeting completion of the negotiations by June 1997."

During the February 1 to 8 talks in Utrecht, the two sides reached several preliminary agreements, including the mode for releasing leftist leader Danilo Borjal who is currently held in a Philippine prison, Ramos said.
They also agreed to set up four working committees to speed up the negotiations, he said.
More than 40,000 people have died in the insurgency war.
The government in June signed a peace accord with the mainstream Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) ending a 24-year revolt for Moslem autonomy in the southern Philippines.
It is currently holding preliminary talks with the breakaway Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) on a separate peace deal. The MILF is fighting for an Islamic state in the southern islands.
The government in October 1995 signed a peace deal with right-wing army rebels involved in six failed coup attempts from 1986 to 1989 against then president Corazon Aquino.
